content: - Area of what is now Turkmenistan forms part of the Persian Empire of Cyrus the Great.
- Alexander the Great of Macedonia conquers Central Asia.
- Arabs conquer Central Asia and convert inhabitants Islam.
- Nomadic Oghuz Seljuk tribes - the ancestors of present-day Turkmens - and Mongols immigrate from northeast; Genghis Khan conquers the region.
- Southern part of modern Turkmenistan comes under Persian rule, while the northern part is dominated by the Uzbek-ruled states of Khiva and Bukhara.
- Area of present-day Turkmenistan incorporated into Russian Turkestan after Battle of Gok Tepe.
- Turkmens join other Central Asians in violently opposing Russian decree conscripting them for non-combatant duties.
- Turkmenistan forms part of the Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic (ASSR).
- Turkmenistan becomes a fully-fledged constituent republic of the USSR.
- Sporadic armed resistance and popular uprisings in response to Soviet programme of agricultural collectivisation and secularisation.
- Over 100,000 killed when earthquake devastates Ashgabat.
- Turkmen cotton production expands dramatically following the completion of the Karakum Canal.
- Saparmurat Niyazov assumes leadership of the Turkmen Communist Party, replacing Muhammad Gapurov, who had held the post since 1971.
- Turkmen fledgling opposition sets up Agzybirlik people's front, which is banned by the Turkmen Communist Party the following year.
- Turkmen parliament declares sovereignty and elects Saparmurat Niyazov as its chairman.
- Saparmurat Niyazov supports attempted coup against Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, but declares independence just before the collapse of the USSR; joins Commonwealth of Independent States.

- Turkmenistan adopts a new constitution making the president head of government as well as head of state and giving him the option to appoint a prime minister at any time; President Niyazov re-elected in direct popular ballot in which he stood unopposed.
- Turkmenistan introduces the manat as its national currency, begins programme of cautious economic reform and encourages foreign investment in its oil and gas reserves.
- Referendum approves extending President Niyazov's term until 2002 without the need for an election.
- Turkmenistan legalises private ownership of land.
- Natural-gas pipeline to Iran opens.
- Parliament votes Saparmurat Niyazov president for life. Death penalty abolished.
- President Niyazov announces that he will step down by 2010, after reaching the age of 70.

- President Niyazov announces plans for a 2,000 sq km artificial lake, to be built in the Karakum desert. The lake would aim to guarantee water supplies, but scientists warn the plan could wreck the local environment.
August - President Niyazov renames the months of the year after himself, his mother and a book he wrote, the Ruhnama.

November - President Niyazov unhurt as his motorcade comes under fire in capital. Authorities blame "mercenaries" acting for exiled opposition leaders who in turn accuse Niyazov of staging incident as excuse to crack down.
Opposition activist and former foreign minister Boris Shikhmuradov is soon arrested, accused of being mastermind and sentenced to life imprisonment. More than 40 others convicted and jailed.
April - Agreement signed with Russian Gazprom monopoly under which Russia will buy 60bn cubic metres of Turkmen gas annually.
President Niyazov decree cancels 1993 dual citizenship agreement with Russia, sparking diplomatic row with Moscow.
August - President Niyazov orders the construction of a giant ice palace in the desert.
November - Turkmen and Uzbek presidents sign friendship declaration, agreement on water resources.
February - President Niyazov undergoes eye operation. Suggests closing hospitals other than those in capital.
May - Deputy Prime Minister Elly Kurbanmuradov, a senior figure in charge of the energy sector, is sacked. He is subsequently jailed for 25 years on charges which include corruption.
July - Rejep Saparov sacked as head of presidential administration and sentenced to 20 years in jail for corruption.
January - President Niyazov orders substantial cuts to state pensions saying he wants to "bring order" to the system.
April - Agreement signed with Beijing on building pipeline to supply Turkmen gas to China.
September - Russia's Gazprom agrees to pay 54% more for supplies of Turkmen gas.
Radio Liberty journalist and human rights activist Ogulsapar Muradova dies in prison. The authorities insist that she died from natural causes but her family dispute this.
21 December - Death of President Niyazov from heart failure is announced.
14 February - Kurbanguly Berdymukhamedov is declared the winner of presidential elections, in which no opposition candidate was allowed.
The Peoples Council promised a multi-party system in 2008
July - Russia, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan agree to build new pipeline north of the Caspian Sea which will ensure Russian access to Turkmen gas.
January - Turkmenistan cuts gas supplies to Iran, blaming a technical fault and Iran's failure to pay for supplies. Iran reacts angrily, saying its neighbour wants to double the price.
April - Turkmenistan reverts to traditional Gregorian calendar.
May - President orders removal of rotating gold statue of his predecessor in Ashgabat.
September - People's Council approves new constitution that replaced it with larger, directly-elected parliament and promise of multi-party system.
December - First elections held under new constitution, still dominated by pro-government candidates.
December - Pipeline opened for gas exports to China, breaking Russia's stranglehold on Turkmenistan's energy reserves.
January - Turkmenistan opens second gas pipeline to Iran.
July - President Berdymukhamedov suggests that private newspapers might be allowed. International media freedom monitors dismiss his comments as window-dressing.

November - Turkmenistan says it will supply gas for the planned Nabucco pipeline, a project to allow EU countries to rely less on Russian supplies. The country says it will have up to 40bn cubic metres (1,412bn cu ft) of spare gas annually.

December - Turkmenistan agrees to the "Tapi" deal to build a pipeline to carry gas across Afghanistan to Pakistan and India. No details are given about funding or how to secure a pipeline that would have to cross the violent Afghan-Pakistan border area.
May - In a move seen as designed to further restrict access to foreign media, President Berdymukhamedov says the number of satellite dishes in Turkmenistan will be limited.
October - Parliament supports a motion conferring the title "hero of the nation" on President Berdymukhamedov.
December - Transparency International names Turkmenistan as joint third most corrupt country in the world.
February - President Berdymukhamedov wins a second term in office, standing against token candidates and securing over 97% of the vote.
August - The Party of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs of Turkmenistan becomes the first political party to be formed in the country since independence from the USSR in 1991.
December - The country's first population census since 1995 takes place.
September - Afghanistan and Turkmenistan sign 30-year gas agreement.
December - Turkmenistan holds first multi-party elections albeit without any credible opposition to the ruling Democratic Party.

November - The four state gas companies of Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and India establish a company that will build, own and operate the planned 1,800-km Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India (TAPI) natural gas pipeline.
January - Turkmenistan devalues its currency by 19 percent against the US dollar - the first such depreciation in almost seven years -  amid a slump in energy prices and a weak Russian rouble.
November - Construction work starts on a $10bn pipeline which will carry gas from Turkmenistan to India, Pakistani and Afghanistan.
September - Constitutional changes extend the presidential term limit from five to seven years ahead of a presidential vote on 12 February 2017.
February - President Berdymukhamedov gains a third term in office.
February - Regional leaders launch construction work on the Afghan section of an $8 billion natural gas pipeline that will link Turkmenistan through Afghanistan to Pakistan and India.
